steps.text: Identify potential fire risks in working machines.
Evaluate each machine's operating environment and conditions.
Issue clear instructions for safety.
Supervise compliance with safety instructions.
Assess fire risks by considering impact on company's other risks, level of risk taken, employee actions in an accident, adequacy of preventive maintenance, and daily work practices.
Begin fire timeline when machine is put into service.
Perform scheduled maintenance according to manufacturer's instructions to ensure proper machine function and participate in recall campaigns.
Use authentic replacement parts for specific machines.
Inspect and clean engine compartment and surroundings daily in dusty or fire-hazard conditions.
Inspect and clean engine compartment and surroundings weekly in other environments.
Clean engine compartment using compressed air after each shift and inspect for leaks.
Inspect fuel leaks by shutting down engine and checking joints of hoses and pipes.
Check oil and hydraulic oil leaks in engine compartment.
Visually inspect electrical systems at least once a year.
Service electrical systems daily on electric-powered and hybrid machines.
Use a multimeter to measure voltage drops in electrical systems.
Use thermal imaging camera to detect anomalies in alternators, cables, and earthing points.
Locate and operate the emergency kill switch before starting machine.
Repair any malfunctions that required emergency kill switch use.
Inspect battery for deviations and ensure cable terminals are intact, firmly attached, and protected.
Check cables not protected by a fuse several times a year.
Replace cables if necessary.
Check for signs of abrasion or heat damage on cables and protect them with a housing pipe.
Keep cables clean and do not attach them to hoses or pipes.
Protect and firmly attach cable harnesses.
Ensure tight cable connections have terminal covers.
Check electric panel during maintenance and repair any redundant or hanging wires.
Ensure fuse boxes are intact with lids and have correct-sized fuses.
Investigate cause of any blown fuse.
For cables in high-vibration engine compartment, fasteners and cable ties should withstand temperatures of 120°C and be no more than 150 mm apart.
Do not attach cables to pipes or hoses containing flammable material.
Firmly attach alternator with correct belt tension and terminal covers.
Keep alternator filter clean to prevent overheating.
Check for anomalies with a thermal camera and replace noisy bearings during maintenance.
During regeneration, ensure it occurs in a safe outdoor environment away from flammable materials.
Delay regeneration if machine is in a fire-hazard environment.
Never leave the machine unattended during regeneration.
Inspect all hoses and electrical systems in the joint weekly.
Remove any rocks or twigs immediately.
Ensure all operating manuals are available and understandable.
Check cleanliness and condition of auxiliary heater, compartment, and wiring before winter.
Test the heater under supervision before use.
Machines in dusty or fire-hazard environments must have a fixed, fully functional fire extinguishing system.
Ensure engine compartments have at least 3L of extinguishing agent per cubic meter.
Install detection system covering entire engine compartment with non-fused cables.
Obtain certificate and test report for installation.
Confirm system operation at start-up.
Repair any malfunctions by authorized shop.
Service system at least once a year.
Clean engine compartments daily.
Shut down engine in case of fire.
Cut electricity from main power switch.
Call for help.
Perform first-aid fire extinguishing.
Confirm fire is out with the fire department.
Report the incident to the safety officer, site manager, coworkers, and insurance company.
Report all accidents and dangerous situations to a supervisor immediately.
Stop and leave the machine in place if possible.
Prevent further damage and minimize injuries.
Wear protective clothing and a helmet.
Use a hands-free device for phone calls.
Wear a safety belt.
Use stepladders and handrails, maintaining three points of contact when climbing.
Keep doors closed during operation.
Ensure tools are secure and emergency exits are marked.
Repair any malfunctions that could lead to an accident without delay.
Arrange practical training on accident and fire procedures.

constraints.text: Working machines must be evaluated for fire risks based on their operating conditions and environment.
Flammable liquids like hydraulic oil, diesel fuel, and motor oil pose a fire risk when hot surfaces reach about 240°C.
Repair any deviations in fuel, oil, and electrical systems immediately.
Ensure cables are checked several times a year, especially lead-throughs.
Ensure a safe environment for regeneration and delay or cancel if necessary.
Machines > 3,000 kg require at least two hand-held fire extinguishers.
Autonomous machines need a fixed fire extinguishing system.
Fire extinguishing systems in autonomous machines must protect hot components, flammable liquid hoses/tanks, and electrical components.
Engine compartments must have clearly marked fire extinguishing openings.
Report all accidents and dangerous situations to a supervisor immediately.
Stop the machine if possible before reporting.
